SENT.plain: An unusual case of a 13-month-old child with Kawasaki's disease and the Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome is presented
The child, while anticoagulated with warfarin and aspirin to prevent extension of a coronary artery thrombus, fell and lacerated the tongue resulting in haemorrhage and significant swelling
The ongoing haemorrhage, combined with difficulty in securing venous access resulted in the child becoming shocked
Surgical intervention was required to stem the haemorrhage
The anaesthetic management of a shocked child with a coronary artery aneurysm and thrombosis, a potentially difficult airway and a full stomach is described
